docs.lead_paragraph: Rona Jaffe, the preternaturally youthful writer whose 1958 novel ''The Best of Everything'' told the melodramatic story of four nubile, cashmere-sweatered career girls torn between storybook romance and cutthroat corporate Manhattan, died yesterday at University College Hospital in London, where she was on vacation. She was 74. She died of cancer, said Alan C. Rothfeld, her lawyer and longtime friend.

headline.main: Rona Jaffe, Author of Popular Novels, Is Dead at 74

docs.snippet: Rona Jaffe's 1958 novel "The Best of Everything" told the melodramatic story of four nubile, cashmere-sweatered career girls in Manhattan.

docs.lead_paragraph: The puffy white coat with the fake fur trim fit perfectly. Lindsay Dunlap stood in the Gap in Chelsea and inspected herself in the mirror. She had lost 30 pounds after separating from her husband. Now Ms. Dunlap, 24, wanted a coat that showed off her trimmer six-foot figure. It was the kind of fashion decision people make dozens of times a year -- this one or that one? Can I afford it? How does it make me look?

headline.main: Where Coats Go for a Second Chance

docs.snippet: A white puffy coat traveled 20 miles through three boroughs in three days on a holiday journey to redemption.

docs.lead_paragraph: AMY SEMINSKI hates gyms. ''Every time I've been, it felt very crowded, and I felt uncomfortable with so many people around,'' she said. ''I didn't like sharing machines or waiting for equipment.'' But she felt that her workout routine -- mainly running and doing yoga several times a week -- was not comprehensive enough, so she did what any good New Yorker would do: she had the gym delivered.

headline.main: Physical Culture; Home Workouts: No Lines, Fees or Strangers

docs.snippet: Forget the gym. With a little ingenuity, you can work out without leaving the home.
